sec.title: More Equality, More Justice
sec.p: I recently completed my ninth year as a high school instrumental music teacher in New York City. This fall I will be beginning my full-time doctoral studies at Teachers College.

I am writing to let you know how much I enjoyed the June 2012 issue of Music Educators Journal. The themes covered—social justice, equality for all—are so important to our field, yet are too rarely discussed in professional literature.

In particular, I thoroughly enjoyed Lisa C. DeLorenzo’s piece, “Missing Faces from the Orchestra.” I have never read an article that has so accurately captured the challenges faced by both educators and students, especially in urban settings. While reading, I found myself frequently exclaiming, “Exactly!” This will be an article that I will often refer back to throughout my professional career.

I must also note that I was very impressed by the article coauthored by Randall Everett Allsup (my mentor and future professor) and Eric Shieh, “Social Justice and Music Education: The Call for a Public Pedagogy,” as it, too, addressed issues not discussed frequently enough among our professional community.
Congratulations on such a fine issue! I truly hope that there will be more issues similar to this one in the future.

boxed-text.title: Letters to the Editor
boxed-text.p: Were you inspired, entertained, or irked by something you read in Music Educators Journal? MEJ academic editor Patrick K. Freer would be interested to know what you think. Please send your comments to him at pfreer@gsu.edu. Kindly include your full name, title, school or institution, and city and state where you teach, or where you live if retired. Letters may be edited for style and length.
